Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Impacts of Impurities on Processing
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Impurities exist in almost all raw materials and precursors and the removal of such impurities can be time-consuming, energy intensive and very costly. In contrast, this project is to investigate the positive impacts impurities can have to promote the development of high energy crystal facets, and surface and bulk defects in a model system, vanadium pentoxide, with much desired chemical, electrochemical, and catalytic properties for energy conversion and storage. These impurities can modify the bulk and surface chemistry, morphology, crystallinity, and the physical properties of the resulting crystallites, and thereby significantly impact their performance and applications. Although the doping in semiconductors (at the electronic grade or ppm level) and the doping in oxides for ionic conductors (at metallurgical grade or a few percent) have been well studied and understood, there is limited information on the impacts of impurities on the processing, morphology, and properties of the resulting crystallites that are widely used in energy conversion and storage as well as many other applications including environment monitoring and remediation.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This project is to investigate the influences and impacts of impurities on the processing, morphology and properties of inorganic materials with vanadium pentoxide as a model system, focusing on submicrometer or nanometer sizes, and their applications in energy conversion and storage. Impurities, often accompanied with other defects such as oxygen vacancies may also be incorporated into the crystal lattice or reside on the surface. Such impurities can modify the bulk and surface chemistry, crystallinity, morphology, and the physical properties of the resulting crystallites away from thermodynamic equilibrium and, thus, significantly impact on their performance and applications with much reduced processing cost. The results generated by this project will enrich the fundamental understanding of the impurities on the processing, morphologies and properties of materials. Broader impacts are envisioned through the recruitment of diverse students; fostering a positive culture that accepts, respects, and tolerates differences of others; training of both undergraduate and graduate students; incorporating recent research results into courses; and working cooperatively with Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The most significant results include the experimental evidences showing the surface energy have appreciable impacts on the electrochemical intercalation reactions, and the surface energy can be manipulated through the incorporation of impurities (dopants), the introduction of surface defects, primarily the oxygen vacancies through controlled post-synthesis annealing at different temperature and different gases or through in-situ synthesis. The crystallinity and morphologies have appreciable impacts on the electrochemical intercalation properties as well. For example, Na-preinserted V2O5 demonstrated much enhanced electrochemical properties and performance for lithium ion storage. Surface oxygen vacancies in V2O5 introduced through thermal annealing in H2, accompanied with V4+ were found to increase the surface energy, catalyze lithium ion intercalation reactions, and facilitate phase transition during charge-discharge cycles.  

A high performance anode material, MnNCN, was synthesized and the relationship between electrochemical properties and chemical composition was explored. MnNCN with long bonding length of 2.26 A in Mn-N and weak electronegativity of 3.04 Pauling units in N leads to a lower charge/discharge potential than that of MnO owing to the character of chemical bonds transformed to covalent-dominating from ionic-dominating in MnO. Covalent character increases the ratio of sharing electrons that decreases the migration energy of electrons in electrochemical reactions, which enhances the reactive reversibility and stability of electrode material. MnNCN delivered a reversible specific capacity of 385 mAh/g at 5 A/g. In addition, Li-ion diffusion and lithiation kinetics in mesocrystal MnO were investigated in relation to morphologies and impurities. Metastable MnS was also studied and compared with stable MnS as an anode for lithium ion batteries and demonstrated the metastable phase is a better choice.

Mo-based compounds including MoO2 and MoSe2 in combination with secondary or impurity phase were investigated. The incoporation of SnO2, anchored to MoSe2 nanosheets resulted in a large specific surface area and a charge accumulation at the interface and promoted sodium-ion transport. The controlled growth of oriented interlayed-expanded MoSe2 nanosheests on graphene with Mo-C bonding demonstrated strong electronic coupling facilitates both electron and Na ion transfer across the interface and reversible insertion and extraction. Similarly, a heterostructure consisting of MoO2 nanoclusters coupled with MoSe2-graphebe nanosheets presents space-accommodation to prevne the structural collapse and, thus, displays a high rate capacity.

This study has been focused on the fundamental understanding of the impacts of impurities/dopants on the morphologies and electrochemical properties using low lost electroactive materials for potential applications in next generation rechargeable batteries. The results found in this study would help and guide the research on the materials science and enginering, most particularly on the clean energy related applications including rechargeable batteries, pseudocapacitors, hybrid battery-capacitors, and catalysts. This research has resulted in a total number of 41 journal publications plus 3 manuscripts submitted for possible journal publications. The PI and the group members have made more than 40 presentations at national and international conferences as well as other research institutes or universities. The research results have also been incorporated to the PI's undergraduate and graduate classes.

The research has trained a number of junior scientists and students including 10 graduate students, 3 visiting scholars, 2 undergraduates and 2 high school students.


Last Modified: 09/02/2018
Modified by: Guozhong Cao
